idinfo.native: Microsoft Windows XP Version 5.1 (Build 2600) Service Pack 3; ESRI ArcCatalog 9.3.1.3500

descript.abstract: United States Populated Places is a point theme representing populated places in the United States as listed by the Geographic Names Information System .
descript.purpose: Geographic Names Information System, of which U.S. Geographic Names Information System Populated Places is a part, is the official repository of domestic geographic names data; the official vehicle for geographic names use by all departments of the Federal Government; and the source for applying geographic names to Federal electronic and printed products of all types in the United States. The feature locative information has been used in emergency preparedness, marketing, site-selection and analysis, genealogical and historical research, and transportation routing applications.
descript.supplinf:
Largest scale when displaying the data: 1:24,000.
This dataset includes an ESRI layer file symbolizing the features.

citeinfo.title: United States Populated Places, 2010
citeinfo.origin: Economic and Social Research Institute (Reston, Va.)

metainfo.metstdn: FGDC Content Standards for Digital Geospatial Metadata

cntorgp.cntorg: Research Data Services (RDS), Columbia University Libraries

enttyp.enttypd: The points represent physical and cultural geographic features located throughout the United States and its Territories.

attrdomv.udom: Sequential unique whole numbers that are automatically generated.

attr.attrdef: The name of the geographic feature. It is the proper name, specific term, or expression by which a particular geographic entity is, or was, known.
attr.attrdefs: United States Geological Survey, United States Board on Geographic Names

codesetd.codesetn: Principles, Policies, and Procedures: Domestic Geographic Names
codesetd.codesets: Principles, Policies, and Procedures: Domestic Geographic Names, By Donald J. Orth, Executive Secretary, Domestic Geographic Names (emeritus) and Roger L. Payne, Executive Secretary, United States Board on Geographic Names and Domestic Geographic Names, Third printing (revised) and Preliminary Online Edition, 1997

attr.attrdef: The combined state/territory and county code (five-digit number). The combined code uniquely identifies the county in which the geographic feature is located.

codesetd.codesetn: INCITS 38:200x, (Formerly FIPS 5-2) Codes for the Identification of the States, the District of Columbia, Puerto Rico, and the Insular Areas of the United States; INCITS 31:200x, (Formerly FIPS 6-4) Codes for the Identification of Counties and Equivalent Entities of the United States, its Possessions, and Insular Areas

attr.attrdef: The elevation of the feature in meters relative to sea level.

digtinfo.formspec: The SDC file contains the geospatial and attribute data. The SDI file contains the spatial index. The PRJ file contains the coordinate system information (optional). The XML file (*.sdc.xml) contains the metadata describing the data set (optional).

stdorder.ordering: ESRI Data & Maps is available only as part of ESRI software.

distinfo.techpreq: To use this data requires software that supports SDC files.

Outside the United States, please direct all inquiries to your local ESRI Office. This information can be found at http://www.esri.com/company/locations.html.

citeinfo.title: U.S. Geographic Names Information System (GNIS)
citeinfo.othercit: The web page is titled 'U.S. Board on Geographic Names: Domestic Names - State and Topical Gazetteer Download Files'. The data set was last revised on October 2, 2009. Downloaded the NationalFile_20091002.zip file.

procstep.procdesc:
GNIS Phase I data compilation and edit - Feature name and attribute data were collected from the largest-scale USGS topographic maps available. These data were compared to the records of the U.S. Board on Geographic Names. This phase is complete.
GNIS Phase II data compilation and edit - Feature name and attribute data are collected from official state and local sources and other approved sources including historical maps and documents. This phase is not complete.
GNIS Maintenance program - Federal and state maintenance cooperators submit new and corrected data in conjunction with their mapping and geographical information system data maintenance programs. The GNIS has an active data gathering and maintenance program. A web-based data entry and edit application allows authorized users to submit transaction data directly for validation and entry into the database, where it immediately becomes available to all web services and applications. A test and demonstration site is available. Government agencies at all levels are encouraged to join this program. Other organizations and individuals will be considered on a case basis.
Partnerships - the Geographic Names Project enters into partnerships with State names authorities and State and local GIS agencies to integrate name, location, and attribute data in the GNIS with State and local datasets. These partnerships utilize GIS and web technology to automate and simplify data maintenance, ensure data consistency, integrity, and accuracy, and meet the requirements of the Board on Geographic Names for national names standardization. Government agencies at all levels are encouraged to join this program. Other organizations and individuals will be considered on a case basis.

The following steps were performed by ESRI: Downloaded the tabular file from the U.S. Geological Survey web site. Converted the file (containing latitude and longitude coordinates) to a shapefile in ArcMap™. Re-projected Alaska and Hawaii to improve their alignment. Reselected out the nine GNIS data sets based on their class types. Removed features with incorrect coordinates and whose NAME contains the word 'Squaw'. Added the STCTYFIPS fields and populated them using source STATE and COUNTY fields. Adjusted the widths of the NAME fields. Converted the data sets to SDC. Created their ArcGIS layer files (.lyr), projection files (.prj), and spatial indices.

horizpa.horizpar:
The geospatial part of this data set was calculated from latitude/longitude coordinates.
The source data is based upon the use of printed or electronic source graphics which are compiled to meet National Map Accuracy Standards.

dataqual.logic: The shapefile is converted to SDC (Smart Data Compression) format using either tools in ArcGIS or ESRI SDC Data Development Kit Professional 2 (DDKP2). The SDC data set is then imported into a file geodatabase to verify and validate the geometry.
dataqual.complete: After processing, the data set is checked for drawing display and number of records and file sizes compared with source materials.
